title: Display multiline string in the debug view tooltips as actual multiline strings.

labels.name: *caused-by-extension
labels.description: Issue identified to be caused by an extension

body: At the moment tooltips in the debugging view show multiline strings as single line strings. Line breaks are shown in their escaped form. This makes it hard to read multi line strings when debugging, especially when dealing with long strings. These are barely readable when you are debugging with VS Code. Therefore I want to propose that the tooltips in the debugging view show strings as actual multiline strings if they contain line breaks. Current Situation: In comparison Visual Studio allows to view multiline strings in a separate window which is very useful.

title: Terminal output is partially duplicated when resizing (only for complex, multi-line prints)

labels.name: upstream
labels.description: Issue identified as 'upstream' component related (exists outside of VS Code)

labels.name: windows
labels.description: VS Code on Windows issues

labels.name: terminal-conpty
labels.description: Integrated terminal issues related to the ConPTY backend

body: ### VS Code Version 1.90.2 (Please fill in your version if different) ### OS Version Windows 11 (Please fill in your OS version if different) ### Steps to Reproduce: 1. Create a Python script that prints many lines to the console. (e.g., a script that calculates and displays a multi-line report) 2. Run the script in the integrated terminal (e.g., `python my_script.py`). 3. After the output is fully displayed, resize the terminal panel by dragging the sash. 4. Alternatively, hide the terminal panel (Ctrl+J) and then show it again (Ctrl+J). ### Expected Behavior The terminal content should remain as it is, without any duplication. ### Actual Behavior The output content is duplicated and appended to the end of the terminal buffer each time the panel is resized or toggled. This happens in the integrated Powershell terminal. I've noticed that only the latter part of the output (starting from the "Horoscope" grid) is being duplicated. The initial simple `print` statements (like `Birth Number: 22`) are not duplicated. This suggests the issue might be related to how the grid-like output is generated and printed. The Python code responsible for generating the duplicated part looks something like this. It involves building a formatted string with multiple lines and then printing it. ```python # This is a simplified example of the code that generates the duplicated output def display_horoscope_grid(cell_data, secret_source_log): # (Some logic to format cells) print("■ ホロスコープ（生年月日＋数秘）：") display_rows = [[3, 6, 9], [2, 5, 8], [1, 4, 7]] for row in display_rows: formatted_cells = [] for cell_digit in row: # Formatting logic here... formatted_cells.append(f"[{...}]") # Simplified print("".join(formatted_cells))

title: Search not working on in-memory file systems
body:
Type: Bug ### Description When utilizing an in-memory file system through the IFileSystemProvider API (https://code.visualstudio.com/api/references/vscode-api#FileSystemProvider), the search functionality in VS Code appears to be malfunctioning. It only returns results from the open files, while the progress indicator in the search view continues spinning indefinitely, suggesting that the search operation hasn't completed properly. In particular the second issue (operation not finishing) is causing significant problems for Copilot, which seems to rely on search results to be finished. ### Steps to reproduce: Run the sample extension with the in-memory file system `memfs:/` (https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-extension-samples/tree/main/fsprovider-sample) - Execute F1 > MemFS: Setup workspace. - Execute F1 > MemFS: Create Files. - Open the search pane and search for console.log. **Expected behavior**: The search should return results from all files in the in-memory file system. **Actual behavior**: No results are found, and the progress indicator spins continuously, indicating the search process is not concluding. ### Steps to reproduce with Copilot Run the sample extension with the in-memory file system `memfs:/` (https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-extension-samples/tree/main/fsprovider-sample) - Execute F1 > MemFS: Setup workspace. - Execute F1 > MemFS: Create Files. - Open the copilot chat in agent mode and run the prompt `Search for all file containing console.log` **Expected behavior**: Copilot is able to find files containing `console.log` as string **Actual behavior**: Copilot is stuck forever while processing on `Searching text for ...` This makes it nearly impossible to use Copilot on virtual/in-memory file systems like `memfs:/`

title: Add Command Palette and Keybinding Support to Toggle Debug Exception Breakpoints (Raised Exceptions, Uncaught Exceptions, User Uncaught Exceptions)

labels.name: insiders-released
labels.description: Patch has been released in VS Code Insiders

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
### Feature Request:
Currently, in Visual Studio Code, toggling exception breakpoints such as:

    Raised Exceptions

    Uncaught Exceptions

    User Uncaught Exceptions

can only be done via the UI in the Run and Debug panel. These toggles are not exposed as commands accessible from the Command Palette or assignable in keybindings.json.

#### It would be very useful to:

    Expose these toggle actions as commands (e.g., debug.toggleRaisedExceptions, debug.toggleUncaughtExceptions, etc.)

    Allow these commands to be mapped to keyboard shortcuts.

    Optionally show current toggle state (on/off) in the status bar or via notifications.

#### Why is this useful?

    Helps improve debugging efficiency, especially when switching between different debugging modes frequently.

    Enables power users to automate/debug faster via keyboard.

    Aligns with the philosophy of "everything in VSCode should be accessible by command."

#### Use Case Example:
As a Python developer, I often want to toggle "Raised Exceptions" while debugging different types of errors. It’s time-consuming to use the mouse and navigate through the panel every time.

#### Optional Advanced Suggestion:
Expose API in vscode.debug namespace to allow extensions to programmatically read and toggle these settings.

title: Setting {"explorer.enableUndo": false} not respected when Undo file renaming
body: Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes - VS Code Version: 1.102.3 - OS Version: Win 11 (Windows_NT x64 10.0.22631) Steps to Reproduce: 1. Set setting `"explorer.enableUndo": false` 2. Open a file and write some text 3. Rename the file via the Explorer "Rename..." operation 4. Write some additional text 5. Press Redo (CTRL+Z) until all is done 6. When it comes to redo the rename-operation a confirmation dialog is shown, which seems wrong. **Although** the setting "explorer.enableUndo": false" was set, the confirmation dialog is displayed: **And even** if the other setting `"explorer.confirmUndo": "light"` is set, this confirmation dialog occurs. When pressing `No` I cannot continue with preceding Undo-steps. Only when pressing `Yes`. --- By the way: Woulf it be possible to add a Skip button to the Confirmation dialog, which can be used to skip the Undo of the file operation and can continue with preceding Undo-steps if needed? Like this ...

title: Response Window Does Not Wrap Long Lines in Copilot Chat

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue identified by VS Code Team member as probable bug

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
**Open Chat in New window**

https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/d5cd491a-ddee-46c8-9714-387655867ed1

**Bug Description:**
When Copilot responds with lengthy content, the response window does not automatically wrap long lines. As a result, much of the content extends beyond the visible area, and users must scroll horizontally to view the entire response. This makes it difficult to read and interact with long outputs.

**Expected Behavior:**
The response window should automatically wrap long lines so that all content remains visible without requiring horizontal scrolling.

**Steps to Reproduce:**
1. Trigger Copilot to generate a long response in the VS Code extension.
2. Observe that the response window does not wrap text, and horizontal scrolling is required to view the full content.

**Environment:**

- VS Code version: 1.102.3
- Copilot Chat Extension Version: 0.29.1
- Copilot extension version: 1.350.0
- OS: Windows 11

Thank you!

title: Fix sticky scroll hover listeners piling up
body:
The StickyScrollWidget adds new mouse enter/exit listeners on every render without clearing the old ones so the listeners keep accumulating. Rendering gets very slow once the number of listeners reaches 100000. Fixed by clearing the existing listeners before adding new ones.

labels.description: Verification succeeded

body:
I would like to request the addition of the latest OpenAI OSS models to the available Groq provider list within VS Code.

Specifically, please consider adding the following models:

openai/gpt-oss-20b (currently in preview)
openai/gpt-oss-120b (currently in preview)

You can find more information about these models on Groq's documentation:
https://console.groq.com/docs/model/openai/gpt-oss-20b
https://console.groq.com/docs/model/openai/gpt-oss-120b

Alternatively, if adding these specific models is not feasible in the short term, I would like to request the ability for users to add custom LLM models to existing providers directly within VS Code settings, without having to wait for VS Code updates. This would greatly enhance flexibility for developers who wish to experiment with or utilize new models as they become available.

title: vscode should not inject a common Env name as `BROWSER`  in terminal when ssh connect.
body: Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes/No - VS Code Version: 1.102.3 (Universal) - OS Version: Darwin arm64 24.5.0 Steps to Reproduce: 1. Using ssh connect remote development machine. 2. Open vscode inner terminal 3. Run any node.js script. ```js if(process.env.BROWSER) { //.... } ``` 5. It's already injected a `BROWSER` env var by vscode. vscode should add a prefix, like `__VSCODE__BROWSER` to distinct user define env var. It's easy to conflict with user script. I found it was injected by here: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/main/src/vs/server/node/extensionHostConnection.ts#L63

title: Fix command palette positioning off-screen when restoring saved position
body:
The command palette could become positioned off-screen (e.g., at -259px left coordinate) when restoring a previously saved drag & drop position, making it invisible and inaccessible to users.

## Problem

When users drag the command palette and VS Code saves that position, the stored coordinates could place the widget outside the visible container bounds on subsequent opens. The `updateLayout` method in `QuickInputController` was directly applying the saved `viewState.left` value without any bounds checking:

```typescript
// Before - could position off-screen
style.left = `${Math.round((this.dimension!.width * (this.viewState?.left ?? 0.5)) - (width / 2))}px`;
```

This resulted in the command palette appearing at negative coordinates (like -259px as shown in the issue), effectively hiding it from users.

## Solution

Added bounds checking to ensure the command palette always stays within the container boundaries when restoring from saved position:

```typescript
// After - stays within bounds
let leftPosition = Math.round((this.dimension!.width * (this.viewState?.left ?? 0.5)) - (width / 2));
// Ensure the widget stays within the container bounds
leftPosition = Math.max(0, Math.min(leftPosition, this.dimension!.width - width));
style.left = `${leftPosition}px`;
```

The fix clamps the left position between:
- **Minimum**: 0 (left edge of container)
- **Maximum**: container width - widget width (right edge where widget is fully visible)

This mirrors the existing bounds checking logic already present in the drag & drop controller but applies it during position restoration as well.

## Testing

The fix ensures that regardless of what position was previously saved, the command palette will always be positioned within visible bounds and remain accessible to users.

Fixes #259101.

title: Copilot is not waiting for long running terminal execution to finish

labels.name: *duplicate
labels.description: Issue identified as a duplicate of another issue(s)

labels.name: chat-terminal
labels.description: The run in terminal tool in chat

body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates -->
<!-- Please attach logs to help us diagnose your issue -->

- Copilot Chat Extension Version: 0.29.1
- VS Code Version: 1.102.3
- OS Version: 15.6 (24G84)
- Feature (e.g. agent/edit/ask mode): agent
- Selected model (e.g. GPT 4.1, Claude 3.7 Sonnet): Claude Sonnet 4
- Logs:

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Have test script that runs for 10-15 seconds then outputs something.
2. Prompt Copilot to run the script.
3. It will prompt to execute the command.
4. The script gets run.

Problem:

The output of the script is never captured or analyzed because it runs to long. This also happens for example when you run a vscode task. The extension seems to lack a proper waiting mechanism to wait for it to finish, maybe with a 'timeout'.

Expected:

I expected the command to run, Copilot to wait for it to finish, and Copilot using the output to analyze or decide on next action after it finished.

title: Prevent labels in secondary sidebar when activity bar is at bottom position
body:
When the activity bar is positioned at the bottom, the secondary sidebar should always display icons rather than text labels to maintain visual consistency.

**Problem**: The `canShowLabels` condition in `auxiliaryBarPart.ts` was only excluding the TOP position, allowing labels to be shown when the activity bar was at the bottom position.

**Solution**: Updated the condition to exclude both TOP and BOTTOM positions:

```typescript
// Before
const canShowLabels = position !== ActivityBarPosition.TOP;

// After  
const canShowLabels = position !== ActivityBarPosition.TOP && position !== ActivityBarPosition.BOTTOM;
```

**Behavior**:
- Activity bar at TOP: Icons always shown (unchanged)
- Activity bar at BOTTOM: Icons always shown (changed from potentially showing labels)
- Activity bar at DEFAULT/HIDDEN: User setting controls display (unchanged)

This ensures a consistent icon-based interface when the activity bar is positioned at the top or bottom.

title: MCP Tool Function Names Lose Server Context When Configuring Tools in Chat Mode
body:
**Version:** `1.103.0-insider (Universal)`
**Commit:** `05ca6dd1bd6690aa2be81cc940ec308e5acc1c3d`
**Date:** `2025-08-05T15:44:58.613Z`
**Electron:** `37.2.3`
**ElectronBuildId:** `12035395`
**Chromium:** `138.0.7204.100`
**Node.js:** `22.17.0`
**V8:** `13.8.500258-electron.0`
**OS:** `Darwin arm64 25.0.0`

---

### 🧪 Steps to Reproduce:

1. Define multiple MCP servers in `mcp.json`, e.g., `test-kusto`, `another-kusto`, each exposing identical tool function names like `execute_query`, `list_tables`, etc.
2. In your `.chat` YAML file, use:

   ```yaml
   tools: ['another-kusto']
   ```

   This correctly uses all the tools under the specified MCP server.
3. Click **"Configure Tools..."** from the UI.
4. Select a **subset of tools** via checkboxes.
5. Observe that the YAML now has individual **function names** under `tools:`, e.g.:

   ```yaml
   tools: ['execute_query', 'list_tables']
   ```

   — **without** MCP server prefix.
6. Click **"Configure Tools..."** again.
7. Now you'll see the same functions marked as selected across **both MCP servers**, even if only one was originally configured.

---

### ❌ Observed Behavior:

* Tools from **multiple MCP servers with overlapping function names** (e.g., `execute_query`) are treated as the same tool in the UI.
* There’s **no disambiguation** between tool functions coming from different MCP servers.
* The UI marks both MCP servers’ functions as selected, regardless of which server was chosen in the original `.chat` config.
* This breaks the intent of selecting a specific **MCP server + tool subset** in the chat mode YAML.

---

### ✅ Expected Behavior:

* When configuring tools via the UI, tool function names should retain **MCP server context**, e.g. `another-kusto::execute_query`.
* Tool selection should apply only to the **specified MCP server**, and not silently overlap with others.
* The YAML should serialize with something like:

  * Server + function names, e.g.:

    ```yaml
    tools: ['another-kusto::execute_query']
    ```
  * Or preserve the server grouping entirely:

    ```yaml
    tools: ['another-kusto']
    ```

---

### 🔁 Related:

* Possibly related to (or regression of) [[microsoft/vscode#245906](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/245906)](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/245906) where MCP servers originally had function name collisions that were fixed by introducing namespacing.
